post_text: Bryan County Schools remains proactive in its efforts to provide a safe learning environment for its students and staff. In preparation for the school year, the District has accumulated and has deployed over 1,000 gallons of hand sanitizer to our schools, multiple mobile hand sanitizer stations at each site; as well as, hand sanitizer in every classroom and on every bus. In addition to increased and intensified cleaning schedules, the District is providing an additional layer of protection. Bryan County Schools has contracted with the Ecovasive Virus and Infection Control Application team to ensure all sites and buses are properly disinfected before the start of the new school year. The treatment will encompass all surface areas and will provide protection against viruses, bacteria, germs, mold and mildew, including COVID-19. Jason Rogers, Assistant Superintendent of Operations, said, “Bryan County Schools is excited about opening its doors on August 17th. We remain committed to doing everything we can to make certain all of our buses and buildings are safe and properly sanitized.”

Bryan County Schools began its first weekly meal distribution this morning. It is amazing to learn the District provided over 22,000 meals to the children of Bryan County in just one day. While we understand there may have been inconveniences, administration will continue to evaluate how the system can reach more children in as efficient manner as possible especially in times where resources, such as food and milk, remain in a limited supply.
Bryan County Family Connections (912-653-3824) and the United Way of the Coastal Empire (912-651-7750) are additional agencies you might contact should your family require further assistance during this time. Since its inception, the Meals on the Bus and curbside pick-up program has distributed approximately 80,000 meals. This phenomenal effort is a huge testament to the level of dedication and commitment of our employees to the students of Bryan County Schools.

Bryan County Schools joins Georgia School Boards Association's (GSBA) “School Board Member Appreciation Week” celebration to salute the efforts of local school board members. As constitutional officers of Georgia, school board members are responsible for setting educational policies, employing school personnel, providing buildings and equipment, operating a transportation system and disbursing school funds. As community leaders, school board members serve as advocates for the children in local public schools and must study, evaluate and decide what actions are in the best interest of those students.

This Bryan County School Board has been recognized as a 2019 Quality School Board by GSBA.

Thank you for your dedication and hard work on behalf of the children of Bryan County!

Bryan County Schools has six schools that recently received the Georgia Department of Education’s highest recognition for their work with Positive Behavior Intervention and Supports (PBIS) implementation.

Lanier Primary, Richmond Hill Primary, Richmond Hill Elementary, Bryan County Elementary, McAllister Elementary, and Richmond Hill Middle received the Five Star School Climate Rating.

PBIS is an evidence-based, data-driven framework proven to reduce disciplinary incidents, increase a school’s sense of safety and support improved academic outcomes. PBIS is a preventative and proactive framework proven to improve school climate by promoting positive relationships between school personnel, students, families, and other stakeholders. The premise of PBIS is that continual teaching, combined with acknowledgement or feedback of positive student behavior will reduce unnecessary discipline and promote a climate of greater productivity, safety and learning.

Congratulations to everyone!
